intro: Rubus walsemannii, commonly known as the Walsemann blackberry, is a species of bramble native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its thorny stems and compound leaves with serrated edges. The plant produces small, aggregate fruits that are typically dark purple to black in color. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland edges and thickets. Botanically, it is part of the Rubus genus, which includes many species of brambles and blackberries.
